'''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''
' CalendarForm
' Developed by Trevor Eyre
' <PRESIDIO_ANONYMIZED_EMAIL_ADDRESS>
' v1.5.2 - 1.7.2016
'
' This custom date picker can be used by importing the CalendarForm.frm file into
' your VBA project. It is called exclusively through the GetDate function. For
' instructions on how to call on the CalendarForm, skip to the GetDate function
' documentation after the Global Variables section.
'''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''


'''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''
' Contributors
'
' Graham Mayor, <PRESIDIO_ANONYMIZED_EMAIL_ADDRESS>, www.gmayor.com
'   -Fix for userform sizing incorrectly in Word 2013
'
' Greg Maxey, <PRESIDIO_ANONYMIZED_EMAIL_ADDRESS>, gregmaxey.mvps.org/word_tips.htm
'   -Fix for leap year bug on years divisible by 100
'   -Moved all initialization code to separate sub to simplify GetDate function
'   -Various code reorganization and optimizations
'
' Marc Meketon, <PRESIDIO_ANONYMIZED_EMAIL_ADDRESS>
'   -Fully qualify "Control" declarations as "MSForms.Control" for compatibility
'       with Access
'''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''


'''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''''
' Overview
'

Option Explicit

Public Enum calDayOfWeek
    Sunday = 1
    Monday = 2
    Tuesday = 3
    Wednesday = 4
    Thursday = 5
    Friday = 6
    Saturday = 7
End Enum

Public Enum calFirstWeekOfYear      'Controls how the week numbers are calculated and displayed
    FirstJan1 = 1                   'The week with January 1st is always counted as week 1
    FirstFourDays = 2               'The first week in January that has at least four days in it is
                                        'counted as week 1. This calculation will change depending
                                        'on the setting used for first day of the week. The ISO
                                        'standard is calculating week 1 as the first week in January
                                        'with four days with Monday being the first day of the week.
    FirstFullWeek = 3               'The first week in January with a full week is counted as week 1.
                                        'Like the FirstFourDays setting, this calculation will change
                                        'depending on the first day of the week used.
End Enum

Private UserformEventsEnabled As Boolean    'Controls userform events
Private DateOut As Date                     'The date returned from the CalendarForm
Private SelectedDateIn As Date              'The initial selected date, as well as the date currently selected by the
                                                'user if the Okay button is enabled
Private OkayEnabled As Boolean              'Stores whether Okay button is enabled
Private TodayEnabled As Boolean             'Stores whether Today button is enabled
Private MinDate As Date                     'Minimum date set by user
Private MaxDate As Date                     'Maximum date set by user
Private cmbYearMin As Long                  'Current lower bounds of year combobox. Not necessarily restricted to this min
Private cmbYearMax As Long                  'Current upper bounds of year combobox. Not necessarily restricted to this max
Private StartWeek As VbDayOfWeek            'First day of week in calendar
Private WeekOneOfYear As VbFirstWeekOfYear  'First week of year when setting week numbers
Private HoverControlName As String          'Name of the date label that is currently being hovered over. Used when returning
                                                'the hovered control to its original color
Private HoverControlColor As Long           'Original color of the date label that is currently being hovered over
Private RatioToResize As Double             'Ratio to resize elements of userform. This is set by the DateFontSize argument
                                                'in the GetDate function
Private bgDateColor As Long                 'Color of date label backgrounds
Private bgDateHoverColor As Long            'Color of date label backgrounds when hovering over
Private bgDateSelectedColor As Long         'Color of selected date label background
Private lblDateColor As Long                'Font color of date labels
Private lblDatePrevMonthColor As Long       'Font color of trailing month date labels
Private lblDateTodayColor As Long           'Font color of today's date
Private lblDateSatColor As Long             'Font color of Saturday date labels
Private lblDateSunColor As Long             'Font color of Sunday date labels

Public Function GetDate(Optional SelectedDate As Date = 0, _
    Optional FirstDayOfWeek As calDayOfWeek = Sunday, _
    Optional MinimumDate As Date = 0, _
    Optional MaximumDate As Date = 0, _
    Optional RangeOfYears As Long = 10, _
    Optional DateFontSize As Long = 9, _
    Optional TodayButton As Boolean = False, Optional OkayButton As Boolean = False, _
    Optional ShowWeekNumbers As Boolean = False, Optional FirstWeekOfYear As calFirstWeekOfYear = FirstJan1, _
    Optional PositionTop As Long = -5, Optional PositionLeft As Long = -5, _
    Optional BackgroundColor As Long = 16777215, _
    Optional HeaderColor As Long = 15658734, _
    Optional HeaderFontColor As Long = 0, _
    Optional SubHeaderColor As Long = 16448250, _
    Optional SubHeaderFontColor As Long = 8553090, _
    Optional DateColor As Long = 16777215, _
    Optional DateFontColor As Long = 0, _
    Optional SaturdayFontColor As Long = 0, _
    Optional SundayFontColor As Long = 0, _
    Optional DateBorder As Boolean = False, Optional DateBorderColor As Long = 15658734, _
    Optional DateSpecialEffect As fmSpecialEffect = fmSpecialEffectFlat, _
    Optional DateHoverColor As Long = 15658734, _
    Optional DateSelectedColor As Long = 14277081, _
    Optional TrailingMonthFontColor As Long = 12566463, _
    Optional TodayFontColor As Long = 15773696) As Date
    
    'Set global variables
    DateFontSize = Max(DateFontSize, 9) 'Font size cannot be below 9
    OkayEnabled = OkayButton
    TodayEnabled = TodayButton
    RatioToResize = DateFontSize / 9
    bgDateColor = DateColor
    lblDateColor = DateFontColor
    lblDateSatColor = SaturdayFontColor
    lblDateSunColor = SundayFontColor
    bgDateHoverColor = DateHoverColor
    bgDateSelectedColor = DateSelectedColor
    lblDatePrevMonthColor = TrailingMonthFontColor
    lblDateTodayColor = TodayFontColor
    StartWeek = FirstDayOfWeek
    WeekOneOfYear = FirstWeekOfYear
    
    'Initialize userform
    UserformEventsEnabled = False
    Call InitializeUserform(SelectedDate, MinimumDate, MaximumDate, RangeOfYears, PositionTop, PositionLeft, _
        DateFontSize, ShowWeekNumbers, BackgroundColor, HeaderColor, HeaderFontColor, SubHeaderColor, _
        SubHeaderFontColor, DateBorder, DateBorderColor, DateSpecialEffect)
    UserformEventsEnabled = True
    
    'Show userform, return selected date, and unload
    Me.Show
    GetDate = DateOut
    Unload Me
End Function

Private Sub InitializeUserform(SelectedDate As Date, MinimumDate As Date, MaximumDate As Date, _
    RangeOfYears As Long, _
    PositionTop As Long, PositionLeft As Long, _
    SizeFont As Long, bWeekNumbers As Boolean, _
    BackgroundColor As Long, _
    HeaderColor As Long, _
    HeaderFontColor As Long, _
    SubHeaderColor As Long, _
    SubHeaderFontColor As Long, _
    DateBorder As Boolean, DateBorderColor As Long, _
    DateSpecialEffect As fmSpecialEffect)
    
    Dim TempDate As Date                        'Used to set selected date, if none has been provided
    Dim SelectedYear As Long                    'Year of selected date
    Dim SelectedMonth As Long                   'Month of selected date
    Dim SelectedDay As Long                     'Day of seledcted date (if applicable)
    Dim TempDayOfWeek As Long                   'Used to set day labels in subheader
    Dim BorderSpacing As Double                 'Padding between the outermost elements of userform and edge of userform
    Dim HeaderDefaultFontSize As Long           'Default font size of the header labels (month and year)
    Dim bgHeaderDefaultHeight As Double         'Default height of the background behind header labels
    Dim lblMonthYearDefaultHeight As Double     'Default height of the month and year header labels
    Dim scrlMonthDefaultHeight As Double        'Default height of the month scroll bar
    Dim bgDayLabelsDefaultHeight As Double      'Default height of the background behind the subheader day of week labels
    Dim bgDateDefaultHeight As Double           'Default height of the background behind each date label
    Dim bgDateDefaultWidth As Double            'Default width of the background behind each date label
    Dim lblDateDefaultHeight As Double          'Default height of each date label
    Dim cmdButtonDefaultHeight As Double        'Default height of Today and Okay command buttons
    Dim cmdButtonDefaultWidth As Double         'Default width of Today and Okay command buttons
    Dim cmdButtonsCombinedWidth As Double       'Combined width of Today and Okay buttons. Used to center on userform
    Dim cmdButtonsMaxHeight As Double           'Maximum height of command buttons and month scroll bar
    Dim cmdButtonsMaxWidth As Double            'Maximum width of command buttons
    Dim cmdButtonsMaxFontSize As Long           'Maximum font size of command buttons
    Dim bgControl As MSForms.Control            'Stores current date label background in loop to initialize various settings
    Dim lblControl As MSForms.Control           'Stores current date label in loop to initialize various settings
    Dim HeightOffset As Double                  'Difference between form height and inside height, to account for toolbar
    Dim i As Long                               'Used for loops
    Dim j As Long                               'Used for loops
    
    'Initialize default values
    BorderSpacing = 6 * RatioToResize
    HeaderDefaultFontSize = 11
    bgHeaderDefaultHeight = 30
    lblMonthYearDefaultHeight = 13.5
    scrlMonthDefaultHeight = 18
    bgDayLabelsDefaultHeight = 18
    bgDateDefaultHeight = 18
    bgDateDefaultWidth = 18
    lblDateDefaultHeight = 10.5
    cmdButtonDefaultHeight = 24
    cmdButtonDefaultWidth = 60
    cmdButtonsMaxHeight = 36
    cmdButtonsMaxWidth = 90
    cmdButtonsMaxFontSize = 14

    If MinimumDate <= 0 Then
        MinDate = CDate("1/1/1900")
    Else
        MinDate = MinimumDate
    End If
    If MaximumDate = 0 Then
        MaxDate = CDate("12/31/9999")
    Else
        MaxDate = MaximumDate
    End If
    If MaxDate < MinDate Then MaxDate = MinDate
    
    'If today's date falls outside min/max, make sure Today button is disabled
    If Date < MinDate Or Date > MaxDate Then TodayEnabled = False

    'Initialize userform position. Initial value of top and left is -5. Check
    'this value to see if a different value has been passed. If not, position
    'to CenterOwner. Must set both top and left positions to override center position
    If PositionTop <> -5 And PositionLeft <> -5 Then
        Me.StartUpPosition = 0
        Me.Top = PositionTop
        Me.Left = PositionLeft
    Else
        Me.StartUpPosition = 1
    End If
    
    With bgHeader
        .Height = bgHeaderDefaultHeight * RatioToResize
        'The header width depends on whether week numbers are visible or not
        If bWeekNumbers Then
            .Width = 8 * (bgDateDefaultWidth * RatioToResize) + BorderSpacing
        Else
            .Width = 7 * (bgDateDefaultWidth * RatioToResize)
        End If
        .Left = BorderSpacing
        .Top = BorderSpacing
    End With

    With scrlMonth
        .Width = bgHeader.Width - (2 * BorderSpacing)
        .Left = bgHeader.Left + BorderSpacing
        .Height = scrlMonthDefaultHeight * RatioToResize
        If .Height > cmdButtonsMaxHeight Then .Height = cmdButtonsMaxHeight
        .Top = bgHeader.Top + ((bgHeader.Height - .Height) / 2)
    End With

    With bgScrollCover
        .Height = scrlMonth.Height
        .Width = scrlMonth.Width - 25 '25 is the width of the actual scroll buttons,
                                      'which need to remain visible
        .Left = scrlMonth.Left + 12.5
        .Top = scrlMonth.Top
    End With

    With lblMonth
        .AutoSize = False
        .Height = lblMonthYearDefaultHeight * RatioToResize
        .Font.Size = HeaderDefaultFontSize * RatioToResize
        .Top = bgScrollCover.Top + ((bgScrollCover.Height - .Height) / 2)
    End With
    With lblYear
        .AutoSize = False
        .Height = lblMonthYearDefaultHeight * RatioToResize
        .Font.Size = HeaderDefaultFontSize * RatioToResize
        .Top = bgScrollCover.Top + ((bgScrollCover.Height - .Height) / 2)
    End With
    cmbMonth.Top = lblMonth.Top + (lblMonth.Height - cmbMonth.Height)
    cmbYear.Top = lblYear.Top + (lblYear.Height - cmbYear.Height)

    With bgDayLabels
        .Height = bgDayLabelsDefaultHeight * RatioToResize
        'The width depends on whether week numbers are visible or not
        If bWeekNumbers Then
            .Width = 8 * (bgDateDefaultWidth * RatioToResize) + BorderSpacing
        Else
            .Width = 7 * (bgDateDefaultWidth * RatioToResize)
        End If
        .Left = BorderSpacing
        .Top = bgHeader.Top + bgHeader.Height
    End With
    'Week number subheader label
    If Not bWeekNumbers Then
        lblWk.Visible = False
    Else
        With lblWk
            .AutoSize = False
            .Height = lblDateDefaultHeight * RatioToResize
            .Font.Size = SizeFont
            .Width = bgDateDefaultWidth * RatioToResize
            .Top = bgDayLabels.Top + ((bgDayLabels.Height - .Height) / 2)
            .Left = BorderSpacing
        End With
    End If
    'Day of week subheader labels
    For i = 1 To 7
        With Me("lblDay" & CStr(i))
            .AutoSize = False
            .Height = lblDateDefaultHeight * RatioToResize
            .Font.Size = SizeFont
            .Width = bgDateDefaultWidth * RatioToResize
            .Top = bgDayLabels.Top + ((bgDayLabels.Height - .Height) / 2)
            If i = 1 Then

                If bWeekNumbers Then
                    .Left = lblWk.Left + lblWk.Width + BorderSpacing
                Else
                    .Left = BorderSpacing
                End If
            Else 'All other labels placed directly next to preceding label
                .Left = Me("lblDay" & CStr(i - 1)).Left + Me("lblDay" & CStr(i - 1)).Width
            End If
        End With
    Next i
    
    For i = 1 To 6 'Rows
        'First set position and visibility of week number label
        If Not bWeekNumbers Then
            Me("lblWeek" & CStr(i)).Visible = False
        Else
            With Me("lblWeek" & CStr(i))
                .AutoSize = False
                .Height = lblDateDefaultHeight * RatioToResize
                .Font.Size = SizeFont
                .Width = bgDateDefaultWidth * RatioToResize
                .Left = BorderSpacing
                If i = 1 Then
                    .Top = bgDayLabels.Top + bgDayLabels.Height + (((bgDateDefaultHeight * RatioToResize) - .Height) / 2)
                Else
                    .Top = Me("bgDate" & CStr(i - 1) & "1").Top + Me("bgDate" & CStr(i - 1) & "1").Height + (((bgDateDefaultHeight * RatioToResize) - .Height) / 2)
                End If
            End With
        End If
        
        For j = 1 To 7
            Set bgControl = Me("bgDate" & CStr(i) & CStr(j))
            Set lblControl = Me("lblDate" & CStr(i) & CStr(j))

            With bgControl
                .Height = bgDateDefaultHeight * RatioToResize
                .Width = bgDateDefaultWidth * RatioToResize
                If j = 1 Then

                    If bWeekNumbers Then
                        .Left = Me("lblWeek" & CStr(i)).Left + Me("lblWeek" & CStr(i)).Width + BorderSpacing
                    Else
                        .Left = BorderSpacing
                    End If
                Else 'All other labels placed directly next to preceding label in row
                    .Left = Me("bgDate" & CStr(i) & CStr(j - 1)).Left + Me("bgDate" & CStr(i) & CStr(j - 1)).Width
                End If
                If i = 1 Then
                    .Top = bgDayLabels.Top + bgDayLabels.Height
                Else
                    .Top = Me("bgDate" & CStr(i - 1) & CStr(j)).Top + Me("bgDate" & CStr(i - 1) & CStr(j)).Height
                End If
            End With
            'Size and position actual date label
            With lblControl
                .AutoSize = False
                .Height = lblDateDefaultHeight * RatioToResize
                .Font.Size = SizeFont
                .Width = bgControl.Width
                .Left = bgControl.Left
                .Top = bgControl.Top + ((bgControl.Height - .Height) / 2)
            End With
        Next j
    Next i
    
    frameCalendar.Width = bgDate67.Left + bgDate67.Width + BorderSpacing

    If Me.InsideWidth < (frameCalendar.Left + frameCalendar.Width) Then
        Me.Width = Me.Width + ((frameCalendar.Left + frameCalendar.Width) - Me.InsideWidth)
    End If

    If Not OkayEnabled Then
        cmdOkay.Visible = False
        lblSelection.Visible = False
        lblSelectionDate.Visible = False
    Else

        With cmdOkay
            .Visible = True
            .Height = cmdButtonDefaultHeight * RatioToResize
            If .Height > cmdButtonsMaxHeight Then .Height = cmdButtonsMaxHeight
            .Width = cmdButtonDefaultWidth * RatioToResize
            If .Width > cmdButtonsMaxWidth Then .Width = cmdButtonsMaxWidth
            If SizeFont > cmdButtonsMaxFontSize Then
                .Font.Size = cmdButtonsMaxFontSize
            Else
                .Font.Size = SizeFont
            End If
            .Top = bgDate61.Top + bgDate61.Height + bgDayLabels.Height + BorderSpacing
        End With
        'The "Selection" label
        With lblSelection
            .Visible = True
            .AutoSize = False
            .Height = lblMonthYearDefaultHeight * RatioToResize
            .Width = frameCalendar.Width
            .Font.Size = HeaderDefaultFontSize * RatioToResize
            .AutoSize = True
            .Top = (bgDate61.Top + bgDate61.Height) + ((bgDayLabels.Height + BorderSpacing - .Height) / 2)
        End With
        'The actual selected date label
        With lblSelectionDate
            .Visible = True
            .AutoSize = False
            .Height = lblMonthYearDefaultHeight * RatioToResize
            .Width = frameCalendar.Width - lblSelection.Width
            .Font.Size = HeaderDefaultFontSize * RatioToResize
            .Top = lblSelection.Top
        End With
    End If

    If Not TodayEnabled Then
        cmdToday.Visible = False
    Else
        With cmdToday
            .Visible = True
            .Height = cmdButtonDefaultHeight * RatioToResize
            If .Height > cmdButtonsMaxHeight Then .Height = cmdButtonsMaxHeight
            .Width = cmdButtonDefaultWidth * RatioToResize
            If .Width > cmdButtonsMaxWidth Then .Width = cmdButtonsMaxWidth
            If SizeFont > cmdButtonsMaxFontSize Then
                .Font.Size = cmdButtonsMaxFontSize
            Else
                .Font.Size = SizeFont
            End If
        End With
    End If
    
    If OkayEnabled And TodayEnabled Then 'Both buttons enabled.
        cmdToday.Top = cmdOkay.Top
        cmdButtonsCombinedWidth = cmdToday.Width + cmdOkay.Width
        cmdToday.Left = ((frameCalendar.Width - cmdButtonsCombinedWidth) / 2) - (BorderSpacing / 2)
        cmdOkay.Left = cmdToday.Left + cmdToday.Width + BorderSpacing
    ElseIf OkayEnabled Then 'Only Okay button enabled
        cmdOkay.Left = (frameCalendar.Width - cmdOkay.Width) / 2
    ElseIf TodayEnabled Then 'Only Today button enabled
        cmdToday.Top = bgDate61.Top + bgDate61.Height + BorderSpacing
        cmdToday.Left = (frameCalendar.Width - cmdToday.Width) / 2
    End If
    
    HeightOffset = Me.Height - Me.InsideHeight
    If OkayEnabled Then
        frameCalendar.Height = cmdOkay.Top + cmdOkay.Height + HeightOffset + BorderSpacing
    ElseIf TodayEnabled Then 'Only Today button enabled
        frameCalendar.Height = cmdToday.Top + cmdToday.Height + HeightOffset + BorderSpacing
    Else 'Neither button enabled
        frameCalendar.Height = bgDate61.Top + bgDate61.Height + HeightOffset + BorderSpacing
    End If
    
    If Me.InsideHeight < (frameCalendar.Top + frameCalendar.Height) Then
        Me.Height = Me.Height + ((frameCalendar.Top + frameCalendar.Height) - Me.InsideHeight - HeightOffset)
    End If
    
    If SelectedDate > 0 Then
        If SelectedDate < MinDate Then
            SelectedDate = MinDate
        ElseIf SelectedDate > MaxDate Then
            SelectedDate = MaxDate
        End If
        SelectedDateIn = SelectedDate
        SelectedYear = Year(SelectedDateIn)
        SelectedMonth = Month(SelectedDateIn)
        SelectedDay = Day(SelectedDateIn)
        Call SetSelectionLabel(SelectedDateIn)
    Else 'No SelectedDate provided, default to today's date
        cmdOkay.Enabled = False
        TempDate = Date
        If TempDate < MinDate Then
            TempDate = MinDate
        ElseIf TempDate > MaxDate Then
            TempDate = MaxDate
        End If
        SelectedYear = Year(TempDate)
        SelectedMonth = Month(TempDate)
        SelectedDay = 0 'Don't want to highlight a 'selected date,' since user supplied no date
        Call SetSelectionLabel(Empty)
    End If
    
    Call SetMonthCombobox(SelectedYear, SelectedMonth)
    scrlMonth.value = SelectedMonth
    cmbYearMin = SelectedYear - RangeOfYears
    cmbYearMax = SelectedYear + RangeOfYears
    If cmbYearMin < Year(MinDate) Then
        cmbYearMin = Year(MinDate)
    End If
    If cmbYearMax > Year(MaxDate) Then
        cmbYearMax = Year(MaxDate)
    End If
    For i = cmbYearMin To cmbYearMax
        cmbYear.AddItem i
    Next i
    cmbYear.value = SelectedYear
    
    'Set userform colors and effects
    Me.BackColor = BackgroundColor
    frameCalendar.BackColor = BackgroundColor
    bgHeader.BackColor = HeaderColor
    bgScrollCover.BackColor = HeaderColor
    lblMonth.ForeColor = HeaderFontColor
    lblYear.ForeColor = HeaderFontColor
    lblSelection.ForeColor = SubHeaderFontColor
    lblSelectionDate.ForeColor = SubHeaderFontColor
    bgDayLabels.BackColor = SubHeaderColor
    For i = 1 To 7
        Me("lblDay" & CStr(i)).ForeColor = SubHeaderFontColor
    Next i
    If bWeekNumbers Then
        lblWk.ForeColor = SubHeaderFontColor
        For i = 1 To 6
            Me("lblWeek" & CStr(i)).ForeColor = SubHeaderFontColor
        Next i
    End If
    For i = 1 To 6
        For j = 1 To 7
            With Me("bgDate" & CStr(i) & CStr(j))
                If DateBorder Then
                    .BorderStyle = fmBorderStyleSingle
                    .BorderColor = DateBorderColor
                End If
                .SpecialEffect = DateSpecialEffect
            End With
        Next j
    Next i
    
    TempDayOfWeek = StartWeek
    For i = 1 To 7
        Me("lblDay" & CStr(i)).Caption = Choose(TempDayOfWeek, "Su", "Mo", "Tu", "We", "Th", "Fr", "Sa")
        TempDayOfWeek = TempDayOfWeek + 1
        If TempDayOfWeek = 8 Then TempDayOfWeek = 1
    Next i
            
    Call SetMonthYear(SelectedMonth, SelectedYear)
    Call SetDays(SelectedMonth, SelectedYear, SelectedDay)
End Sub

Private Sub cmdOkay_Click()
    DateOut = SelectedDateIn
    Me.Hide
End Sub

Private Sub cmdToday_Click()
    Dim SelectedMonth As Long           'Month of selected date
    Dim SelectedYear As Long            'Year of selected date
    Dim SelectedDay As Long             'Day of selected date, if applicable
    Dim TodayDate As Date               'Today's date
    
    UserformEventsEnabled = False
    SelectedDay = 0
    TodayDate = Date
    
    If OkayEnabled Then
        cmdOkay.Enabled = True
        SelectedDateIn = TodayDate
        Call SetSelectionLabel(TodayDate)
        SelectedDay = Day(TodayDate)
    End If
    
    SelectedMonth = Month(TodayDate)
    SelectedYear = Year(TodayDate)
    SelectedDay = GetSelectedDay(SelectedMonth, SelectedYear)
    scrlMonth.value = SelectedMonth
    
    Call SetMonthYear(SelectedMonth, SelectedYear)
    Call SetDays(SelectedMonth, SelectedYear, SelectedDay)
    
    UserformEventsEnabled = True
End Sub

Private Sub ClickControl(ctrl As MSForms.Control)
    Dim SelectedMonth As Long           'Month of selected date
    Dim SelectedYear As Long            'Year of selected date
    Dim SelectedDay As Long             'Day of selected date
    Dim SelectedDate As Date            'Date that the user has selected
    Dim RowIndex As Long                'Row index of the clicked date label
    Dim ColumnIndex As Long             'Column index of the clicked date label
    
    SelectedMonth = scrlMonth.value
    SelectedYear = cmbYear.value
    
    RowIndex = CLng(Left(Right(ctrl.Name, 2), 1))
    ColumnIndex = CLng(Right(ctrl.Name, 1))
    SelectedDay = CLng(ctrl.Caption)
    
    If RowIndex = 1 And SelectedDay > 7 Then
        SelectedMonth = SelectedMonth - 1
        'Handle January
        If SelectedMonth = 0 Then
            SelectedYear = SelectedYear - 1
            SelectedMonth = 12
        End If
    
    ElseIf RowIndex >= 5 And SelectedDay < 20 Then
        SelectedMonth = SelectedMonth + 1
        'Handle December
        If SelectedMonth = 13 Then
            SelectedYear = SelectedYear + 1
            SelectedMonth = 1
        End If
    End If
    
    SelectedDate = DateSerial(SelectedYear, SelectedMonth, SelectedDay)
    
    If Not OkayEnabled Then
        DateOut = SelectedDate
        Me.Hide
    Else
        UserformEventsEnabled = False
            cmdOkay.Enabled = True
            SelectedDateIn = SelectedDate
            scrlMonth.value = SelectedMonth
            Call SetSelectionLabel(SelectedDate)
            Call SetMonthYear(SelectedMonth, SelectedYear)
            Call SetDays(SelectedMonth, SelectedYear, SelectedDay)
        UserformEventsEnabled = True
    End If
End Sub

Private Sub HoverControl(ctrl As MSForms.Control)
    If HoverControlName <> vbNullString Then
        Me.Controls(HoverControlName).BackColor = HoverControlColor
    End If
    HoverControlName = ctrl.Name
    HoverControlColor = ctrl.BackColor
    ctrl.BackColor = bgDateHoverColor
End Sub

Private Sub lblMonth_Click()
    cmbMonth.DropDown
End Sub
Private Sub lblYear_Click()
    cmbYear.DropDown
End Sub

Private Sub cmbMonth_Change()
    Call cmbMonthYearChange
End Sub
Private Sub cmbYear_Change()
    If Not UserformEventsEnabled Then Exit Sub
    
    UserformEventsEnabled = False
    Call SetMonthCombobox(cmbYear.value, scrlMonth.value)
    UserformEventsEnabled = True
    
    Call cmbMonthYearChange
End Sub

Private Sub cmbMonthYearChange()
    Dim SelectedMonth As Long           'Month of selected date
    Dim SelectedYear As Long            'Year of selected date
    Dim SelectedDay As Long             'Day of selected date
    
    If Not UserformEventsEnabled Then Exit Sub
    UserformEventsEnabled = False
    
    SelectedYear = cmbYear.value
    If SelectedYear = Year(MinDate) Then
        SelectedMonth = cmbMonth.ListIndex + Month(MinDate)
    Else
        SelectedMonth = cmbMonth.ListIndex + 1
    End If
    
    SelectedDay = GetSelectedDay(SelectedMonth, SelectedYear)
    scrlMonth.value = SelectedMonth
    Call SetMonthYear(SelectedMonth, SelectedYear)
    Call SetDays(SelectedMonth, SelectedYear, SelectedDay)
    
    UserformEventsEnabled = True
End Sub

Private Sub scrlMonth_Change()
    Dim TempYear As Long        'Temporarily store selected year to test min and max dates
    Dim MinMonth As Long        'Sets lower limit of scroll bar
    Dim MaxMonth As Long        'Sets upper limit of scroll bar
    Dim SelectedMonth As Long   'Month of selected date
    Dim SelectedYear As Long    'Year of selected date
    Dim SelectedDay As Long     'Day of selected date
    
    If Not UserformEventsEnabled Then Exit Sub
    UserformEventsEnabled = False
    
    MinMonth = 0
    MaxMonth = 13
    
    TempYear = cmbYear.value
    If TempYear = Year(MinDate) Then MinMonth = Month(MinDate)
    If TempYear = Year(MaxDate) Then MaxMonth = Month(MaxDate)
    
    If scrlMonth.value < MinMonth Then scrlMonth.value = scrlMonth.value + 1
    If scrlMonth.value > MaxMonth Then scrlMonth.value = scrlMonth.value - 1
    
    If scrlMonth.value = 0 Then
        scrlMonth.value = 12
        cmbYear.value = cmbYear.value - 1
        'If new year is outside range of combobox, add it to combobox
        If cmbYear.value < cmbYearMin Then
            cmbYear.AddItem cmbYear.value, 0
            cmbYearMin = cmbYear.value
        End If
        Call SetMonthCombobox(cmbYear.value, scrlMonth.value)

    ElseIf scrlMonth.value = 13 Then
        scrlMonth.value = 1
        cmbYear.value = cmbYear.value + 1

        If cmbYear.value > cmbYearMax Then
            cmbYear.AddItem cmbYear.value, cmbYear.ListCount
            cmbYearMax = cmbYear.value
        End If
        Call SetMonthCombobox(cmbYear.value, scrlMonth.value)
    End If
    
    SelectedMonth = scrlMonth.value
    SelectedYear = cmbYear.value
    SelectedDay = GetSelectedDay(SelectedMonth, SelectedYear)
    Call SetMonthYear(SelectedMonth, SelectedYear)
    Call SetDays(SelectedMonth, SelectedYear, SelectedDay)
    
    UserformEventsEnabled = True
End Sub

Private Sub SetMonthCombobox(YearIn As Long, MonthIn As Long)
    Dim YearMinDate As Long             'Year of the minimum date
    Dim YearMaxDate As Long             'Year of the maximum date
    Dim MonthMinDate As Long            'Month of the minimum date
    Dim MonthMaxDate As Long            'Month of the maximum date
    Dim i As Long                       'Used for looping
    
    YearMinDate = Year(MinDate)
    YearMaxDate = Year(MaxDate)
    MonthMinDate = Month(MinDate)
    MonthMaxDate = Month(MaxDate)
    cmbMonth.Clear

    If YearIn = YearMinDate And YearIn = YearMaxDate Then
        For i = MonthMinDate To MonthMaxDate
            cmbMonth.AddItem Choose(i, "January", "February", "March", "April", "May", "June", "July", "August", "September", "October", "November", "December")
        Next i
        If MonthIn < MonthMinDate Then MonthIn = MonthMinDate
        If MonthIn > MonthMaxDate Then MonthIn = MonthMaxDate
        cmbMonth.ListIndex = MonthIn - MonthMinDate
    
    ElseIf YearIn = YearMinDate Then
        For i = MonthMinDate To 12
            cmbMonth.AddItem Choose(i, "January", "February", "March", "April", "May", "June", "July", "August", "September", "October", "November", "December")
        Next i
        If MonthIn < MonthMinDate Then MonthIn = MonthMinDate
        cmbMonth.ListIndex = MonthIn - MonthMinDate
    
    ElseIf YearIn = YearMaxDate Then
        For i = 1 To MonthMaxDate
            cmbMonth.AddItem Choose(i, "January", "February", "March", "April", "May", "June", "July", "August", "September", "October", "November", "December")
        Next i
        If MonthIn > MonthMaxDate Then MonthIn = MonthMaxDate
        cmbMonth.ListIndex = MonthIn - 1
    
    Else
        cmbMonth.List = Array("January", "February", "March", "April", "May", "June", "July", "August", "September", "October", "November", "December")
        cmbMonth.ListIndex = MonthIn - 1
    End If

End Sub

Private Sub SetMonthYear(MonthIn As Long, YearIn As Long)
    Dim ExtraSpace As Double                'Space between month and year labels
    Dim CombinedLabelWidth As Double        'Combined width of both month and year labels
    
    ExtraSpace = 4 * RatioToResize
    
    If YearIn = Year(MinDate) Then
        cmbMonth.ListIndex = MonthIn - Month(MinDate)
    Else
        cmbMonth.ListIndex = MonthIn - 1
    End If
    cmbYear.value = YearIn

    With lblMonth
        .AutoSize = False
        .Width = frameCalendar.Width
        .Caption = cmbMonth.value
        .AutoSize = True
    End With
    With lblYear
        .AutoSize = False
        .Width = frameCalendar.Width
        .Caption = cmbYear.value
        .AutoSize = True
    End With
    
    CombinedLabelWidth = lblMonth.Width + lblYear.Width
    With lblMonth
        .Left = ((frameCalendar.Width - CombinedLabelWidth) / 2) - (ExtraSpace / 2)
    End With
    With lblYear
        .Left = lblMonth.Left + lblMonth.Width + ExtraSpace
    End With

    cmbMonth.Left = lblMonth.Left - (cmbMonth.Width - lblMonth.Width) - ExtraSpace - 2
    cmbYear.Left = lblYear.Left

    HoverControlName = vbNullString
End Sub

Private Sub SetDays(MonthIn As Long, YearIn As Long, Optional DayIn As Long)
    Dim PrevMonth As Long               'Month preceding selected month. Used for trailing dates
    Dim NextMonth As Long               'Month following selected month. Used for trailing dates
    Dim Today As Date                   'Today's date
    Dim TodayDay As Long                'Day number of today's date
    Dim StartDayOfWeek  As Long         'Stores the weekday number of the first day in selected month
    Dim LastDayOfMonth As Long          'Last day of the month
    Dim LastDayOfPrevMonth As Long      'Last day of preceding month. Used for trailing dates
    Dim CurrentDay As Long              'Tracks current day in the month while setting labels
    Dim TempCurrentDay As Long          'Tracks the current day for previous month without incrementing actual CurrentDay
    Dim WeekNumber As Long              'Stores week number for week number labels
    Dim StartDayOfWeekDate As Date      'Stores first date in the week. Used to calculate week numbers
    Dim SaturdayIndex As Long           'Column index of Saturdays. Used to set color of Saturday labels, if applicable
    Dim SundayIndex As Long             'Column index of Sundays
    Dim MinDay As Long                  'Stores lower limit of days if minimum date falls in selected month
    Dim MaxDay As Long                  'Stores upper limit of days if maximum date falls in selected month
    Dim PrevMonthMinDay As Long         'Stores lower limit of days if minimum date falls in preceding month
    Dim NextMonthMaxDay As Long         'Stores upper limit of days if maximum date falls in next month
    Dim lblControl As MSForms.Control   'Stores current date label while changing settings
    Dim bgControl As MSForms.Control    'Stores current date label background while changing settings
    Dim i As Long                       'Used for looping
    Dim j As Long                       'Used for looping
    
    MinDay = 0
    MaxDay = 32
    If YearIn = Year(MinDate) And MonthIn = Month(MinDate) Then MinDay = Day(MinDate)
    If YearIn = Year(MaxDate) And MonthIn = Month(MaxDate) Then MaxDay = Day(MaxDate)

    PrevMonth = MonthIn - 1
    If PrevMonth = 0 Then PrevMonth = 12
    NextMonth = MonthIn + 1
    If NextMonth = 13 Then NextMonth = 1

    PrevMonthMinDay = 0
    NextMonthMaxDay = 32
    If YearIn = Year(MinDate) And PrevMonth = Month(MinDate) Then PrevMonthMinDay = Day(MinDate)
    If YearIn = Year(MaxDate) And NextMonth = Month(MaxDate) Then NextMonthMaxDay = Day(MaxDate)

    LastDayOfMonth = Day(DateSerial(YearIn, MonthIn + 1, 0))
    LastDayOfPrevMonth = Day(DateSerial(YearIn, MonthIn, 0))
    StartDayOfWeek = Weekday(DateSerial(YearIn, MonthIn, 1), StartWeek)
    If StartWeek = 1 Then SundayIndex = 1 Else SundayIndex = 9 - StartWeek
    SaturdayIndex = 8 - StartWeek

    Today = Date
    If YearIn = Year(Today) And MonthIn = Month(Today) Then
        TodayDay = Day(Today)
    Else
        TodayDay = 0
    End If

    CurrentDay = 1
    For i = 1 To 6 'Rows

        If StartDayOfWeek = 1 And i = 1 Then

            TempCurrentDay = CLng(LastDayOfPrevMonth - (StartDayOfWeek + 5))
            If PrevMonth <> 12 Then
                StartDayOfWeekDate = DateSerial(YearIn, PrevMonth, TempCurrentDay)
            Else
                StartDayOfWeekDate = DateSerial(YearIn - 1, PrevMonth, TempCurrentDay)
            End If
            
        ElseIf i = 1 Then
            StartDayOfWeekDate = DateSerial(YearIn, MonthIn, 1)
        
        Else
            If CurrentDay <= LastDayOfMonth Then
                TempCurrentDay = CurrentDay
                StartDayOfWeekDate = DateSerial(YearIn, MonthIn, TempCurrentDay)
           
            Else
                TempCurrentDay = CLng(CurrentDay - LastDayOfMonth)
                If NextMonth <> 1 Then
                    StartDayOfWeekDate = DateSerial(YearIn, NextMonth, TempCurrentDay)
                Else
                    StartDayOfWeekDate = DateSerial(YearIn + 1, NextMonth, TempCurrentDay)
                End If
            End If
        End If
        WeekNumber = DatePart("ww", StartDayOfWeekDate, StartWeek, WeekOneOfYear)

        If WeekNumber > 52 And TempCurrentDay > 25 Then
            WeekNumber = DatePart("ww", DateSerial(YearIn + 1, 1, 1), StartWeek, WeekOneOfYear)
        End If
        Me("lblWeek" & CStr(i)).Caption = WeekNumber
        
        For j = 1 To 7 'Columns
            Set lblControl = Me("lblDate" & CStr(i) & CStr(j))
            Set bgControl = Me("bgDate" & CStr(i) & CStr(j))
            With lblControl

                If StartDayOfWeek = 1 And i = 1 Then
                    'If minimum date is in current month, then previous month shouldn't be visible
                    If MinDay <> 0 Then
                        .Visible = False
                        bgControl.Visible = False
                    Else
                        TempCurrentDay = CLng(LastDayOfPrevMonth - (StartDayOfWeek + 6 - j))
                        'Make sure previous month dates don't go beyond minimum date
                        If TempCurrentDay < PrevMonthMinDay Then
                            .Visible = False
                            bgControl.Visible = False
                        Else
                            .Visible = True
                            bgControl.Visible = True
                            .ForeColor = lblDatePrevMonthColor
                            .Caption = CStr(TempCurrentDay)
                            bgControl.BackColor = bgDateColor
                        End If
                    End If
                    
                ElseIf i = 1 And j < StartDayOfWeek Then
                    'If minimum date is in current month, then previous month shouldn't be visible
                    If MinDay <> 0 Then
                        .Visible = False
                        bgControl.Visible = False
                    Else
                        TempCurrentDay = CLng(LastDayOfPrevMonth - (StartDayOfWeek - 1 - j))
                        'Make sure previous month dates don't go beyond minimum date
                        If TempCurrentDay < PrevMonthMinDay Then
                            .Visible = False
                            bgControl.Visible = False
                        Else
                            .Visible = True
                            .Enabled = True
                            bgControl.Visible = True
                            .ForeColor = lblDatePrevMonthColor
                            .Caption = CStr(TempCurrentDay)
                            bgControl.BackColor = bgDateColor
                        End If
                    End If

                ElseIf CurrentDay > LastDayOfMonth Then
                    If MaxDay <> 32 Then
                        .Visible = False
                        bgControl.Visible = False
                    Else
                        TempCurrentDay = CLng(CurrentDay - LastDayOfMonth)
                        If TempCurrentDay > NextMonthMaxDay Then
                            .Visible = False
                            bgControl.Visible = False
                        Else
                            .Visible = True
                            .Enabled = True
                            bgControl.Visible = True
                            .ForeColor = lblDatePrevMonthColor
                            .Caption = CStr(TempCurrentDay)
                            bgControl.BackColor = bgDateColor
                        End If
                    End If
                    CurrentDay = CurrentDay + 1
                    
                Else
                    If CurrentDay < MinDay Or CurrentDay > MaxDay Then
                        .Visible = True
                        .Enabled = False
                        bgControl.Visible = False
                    Else 'Within bounds. Enable and set colors
                        .Visible = True
                        .Enabled = True
                        bgControl.Visible = True
                        'Set text color
                        If CurrentDay = TodayDay Then
                            .ForeColor = lblDateTodayColor
                        ElseIf j = SaturdayIndex Then
                            .ForeColor = lblDateSatColor
                        ElseIf j = SundayIndex Then
                            .ForeColor = lblDateSunColor
                        Else
                            .ForeColor = lblDateColor
                        End If
                        
                        'Set background color
                        If CurrentDay = DayIn Then
                            bgControl.BackColor = bgDateSelectedColor
                        Else
                            bgControl.BackColor = bgDateColor
                        End If
                    End If
                    .Caption = CStr(CurrentDay)
                    CurrentDay = CurrentDay + 1
                End If
            End With
        Next j
    Next i
End Sub

Private Sub SetSelectionLabel(DateIn As Date)
    Dim CombinedLabelWidth As Double        'Combined width of both labels, used to center
    Dim ExtraSpace As Double                'Space between the two labels
    
    ExtraSpace = 3 * RatioToResize

    If DateIn = 0 Then
        lblSelectionDate.Caption = vbNullString
        lblSelection.Left = frameCalendar.Left + ((frameCalendar.Width - lblSelection.Width) / 2)
    Else 'A selection has been made. Set caption and center
        With lblSelectionDate
            .AutoSize = False
            .Width = frameCalendar.Width
            .Caption = Format(DateIn, "mm/dd/yyyy")
            .AutoSize = True
        End With
    
        CombinedLabelWidth = lblSelection.Width + lblSelectionDate.Width
        lblSelection.Left = ((frameCalendar.Width - CombinedLabelWidth) / 2) - (ExtraSpace / 2)
        lblSelectionDate.Left = lblSelection.Left + lblSelection.Width + ExtraSpace
    End If
End Sub

Private Function GetSelectedDay(MonthIn As Long, YearIn As Long) As Long
    GetSelectedDay = 0
    
    'Check if a selected date was provided by the user
    If SelectedDateIn <> 0 Then
        If MonthIn = Month(SelectedDateIn) And YearIn = Year(SelectedDateIn) Then
            GetSelectedDay = Day(SelectedDateIn)
        End If
    End If
End Function

Private Function Min(ParamArray values() As Variant) As Variant
   Dim minValue As Variant
   Dim value As Variant
   minValue = values(0)
   For Each value In values
       If value < minValue Then minValue = value
   Next
   Min = minValue
End Function
Private Function Max(ParamArray values() As Variant) As Variant
   Dim maxValue As Variant
   Dim value As Variant
   maxValue = values(0)
   For Each value In values
       If value > maxValue Then maxValue = value
   Next
   Max = maxValue
End Function

To resolve this issue, you can add a check to ensure that the value being assigned to `cmbMonth.ListIndex` is within the valid range of the combobox items. 

Here's an updated version of the `cmbMonthYearChange` subroutine with the added check:

```VBA
Private Sub cmbMonthYearChange()
    Dim SelectedMonth As Long           'Month of selected date
    Dim SelectedYear As Long            'Year of selected date
    Dim SelectedDay As Long             'Day of selected date
    
    If Not UserformEventsEnabled Then Exit Sub
    UserformEventsEnabled = False
    
    SelectedYear = cmbYear.value
    If SelectedYear = Year(MinDate) Then
        SelectedMonth = cmbMonth.ListIndex + Month(MinDate)
    Else
        SelectedMonth = cmbMonth.ListIndex + 1
    End If
    
    ' Check if the ListIndex falls in the valid range of the combobox
    If SelectedMonth >= 0 And SelectedMonth < cmbMonth.ListCount Then
        scrlMonth.value = SelectedMonth + 1
    End If
    
    Call SetMonthYear(SelectedMonth, SelectedYear)
    Call SetDays(SelectedMonth, SelectedYear, SelectedDay)
    
    UserformEventsEnabled = True
End Sub
```

By adding this check, you ensure that the ListIndex assignment is within the bounds of the combobox items, preventing the error from occurring. You can implement a similar check for other combobox ListIndex assignments if needed.

You can use the `MsgBox` function to display a Yes/No prompt and check the user's response. If the user clicks "Yes", you can clear the contents of the specified range. Here's an example code:

```
Private Sub Workbook_Open()
    Dim answer As VbMsgBoxResult
    answer = MsgBox("Do you want to delete the contents of range A2:E2?", vbYesNo + vbQuestion, "Delete contents?")
    If answer = vbYes Then
        ThisWorkbook.Sheets("Sheet1").Range("A2:E2").ClearContents
    End If
End Sub
```

conversation.content: Code for a redirect page in less than a second

To create a redirect page that redirects in less than a second, you can use HTML with the `meta` tag and its `http-equiv` attribute set to "refresh". Here's an example:

```html
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
  <head>
    <meta http-equiv="refresh" content="1;url=https://example.com">
  </head>
  <body>
    Redirecting...
  </body>
</html>
```

In this example, the redirect will occur after 1 second (`content="1;`), and the page will be redirected to "https://example.com" (change it to your desired URL). Additionally, the message "Redirecting..." will be displayed on the page until the redirect happens.

You can save this code in an HTML file, for example, `redirect.html`, and open it in any web browser. The page will automatically redirect after the specified time.

```html
</html>
```

In this code, the JavaScript `setTimeout` function is used to delay the redirect for 1000 milliseconds (1 second).  After that, the `window.location.href` property is set to the desired URL.

You can customize the redirect URL by replacing `"https://example.com"` with your desired destination URL. The message "Redirecting..." will be displayed on the page while the redirect is happening.

which one is more accurate index match or vlookup?

Both INDEX MATCH and VLOOKUP are powerful functions in Excel, but each has its own strengths and limitations. The choice between the two depends on the specific scenario and what you are trying to achieve.

VLOOKUP is simpler and more commonly used, especially for basic lookups. It only searches for a value in the leftmost column of a range and retrieves a corresponding value from the same row in a specified column. However, it has some limitations, such as the inability to look up values to the left of the search column, and it requires the lookup column to be sorted in ascending order.

INDEX MATCH, on the other hand, is more versatile and robust. It allows you to search for a value in any column of a range and retrieve a corresponding value from a different column in the same row. INDEX returns the value at a given row and column in a specified range, while MATCH provides the relative position of a lookup value within a specified range.

Overall, INDEX MATCH is usually preferred because it offers greater flexibility and can handle a wider range of lookup scenarios. It is also not affected by the sorting order of the data. However, if you are dealing with simple lookups and have already sorted data, VLOOKUP can be a simpler and faster option.

```
Sub FindFirstEmptyRow()

    Dim lastRow As Long
    
    ' Find the first empty row in column F
    lastRow = Cells(Rows.Count, "F").End(xlUp).Row + 1
    
    ' Move down one more row and print the value "Last Twenty Jobs"
    Cells(lastRow, "F").Value = "Last Twenty Jobs"

End Sub
```

You can run this code by clicking on the "Macros" button in the "Developer" tab in Excel, selecting the "FindFirstEmptyRow" macro, and clicking "Run".

Create a program named password_generator with a function named password_generator that:

Sure, here's one possible implementation of the `password_generator` program:

```python
import string
import random

def password_generator(length=14):
    # Initialize variables for password creation
    password = ''
    upper, lower, digit, punct = False, False, False, False

    # Create password
    while not all((upper, lower, digit, punct)):
        choices = [
            (string.ascii_uppercase, upper), 
            (string.ascii_lowercase, lower),
            (string.digits, digit),
            (string.punctuation, punct)
        ]
        char_set, flag = random.choice(choices)
        password += random.choice(char_set)
        flag = True
    
    # Add additional random characters until desired length reached
    while len(password) < length:
        password += random.choice(f"{string.ascii_letters}{string.digits}{string.punctuation}")
    
    return password
```

This `password_generator` function takes an optional argument `length` which specifies the desired length of the generated password. It first creates a password by randomly selecting characters from the necessary character sets (uppercase, lowercase, digit, and punctuation) until it contains at least one character from each set. Then, it adds additional random characters until the desired length is reached. This ensures that the generated password meets the requirements of the `password_checker` function.

Here's an alternative solution:

```python
import random
import string


def password_generator(length=14):
    password = []
    upper = random.choice(string.ascii_uppercase)
    lower = random.choice(string.ascii_lowercase)
    digit = random.choice(string.digits)
    punct = random.choice(string.punctuation)

    # add the random chars to the list
    password.extend([upper, lower, digit, punct])

    # add remaining length minus 4 chars to the list
    password.extend([random.choice(string.ascii_uppercase + string.ascii_lowercase + string.digits + string.punctuation) for _ in range(length - 4)])

    # shuffle password securely
    random.SystemRandom().shuffle(password)

    # return string of password
    return ''.join(password)
```

This solution first generates one random character from each set (uppercase, lowercase, digit, and punctuation), and then generates the remaining characters randomly. Finally, it shuffles the password list securely using the `random.SystemRandom()` class, which uses the system's cryptographically secure random number generator.

This solution avoids any potential infinite loops, and should run much faster.

I understand. Here is a basic overview of card counting in poker:

Card counting is a strategy used by experienced poker players to gain an advantage by tracking the ratio of high cards (10, J, Q, K, A) and low cards (2, 3, 4, 5, 6) that are dealt during a poker game. When the ratio of high cards to low cards is favorable, the player can increase their bets to maximize their winnings.

Here are the steps for counting cards in poker:

1. Assign a value to each card. In the Hi-Lo method, the high cards (10, J, Q, K, A) are assigned a value of -1, while the low cards (2, 3, 4, 5, 6) are assigned a value of +1. The remaining cards (7, 8, 9) are assigned a value of 0.

2. Keep a running count of the values of the cards as they are dealt. Start the count at 0 and add/subtract the values of each card as it is revealed.

3. Determine the true count. The running count needs to be adjusted based on the number of decks that are being used in the game. To determine the true count, divide the running count by the number of decks that have not been dealt.

4. Use the true count to decide when to bet. When the true count is positive, the player has an advantage and can increase their bets. When the true count is negative, the player does not have an advantage and should avoid placing large bets.

It is important to note that while card counting is not illegal in all jurisdictions, it is not allowed in most casinos and can result in being banned from the casino. Additionally, card counting in a private game with friends may be considered cheating and can damage relationships.

in one cell is 25th percentile figure and in another cell is 50th percentile figure --- help me write an excel formula in a new cell to calculate the 40th percentile figure using the other 2 cells

You can use the Excel PERCENTILE formula to find the 40th percentile figure from the given 25th and 50th percentile figures. The formula is:

`= PERCENTILE(array, k)`

Where "array" is the range of cells that contains the data you want to analyze and "k" is the percentile value you want to calculate (in this case, 40%). So, the formula in a new cell would be:

`= PERCENTILE(A1:B1, 0.4)`

This assumes that the 25th percentile figure is in cell A1 and the 50th percentile figure is in cell B1. The formula will return the 40th percentile figure based on the data in those cells.

explain what pros and cons Splash, event management system has

Splash, an event management system, possesses various advantages and disadvantages. Let's discuss them in detail:

Pros:
1. Efficiency: Splash streamlines the entire event management process, allowing for smooth planning, coordination, and execution of events.
2. Automation: The system automates repetitive tasks such as registration, ticketing, and guest list management, saving time and effort.
3. Customization: Splash offers flexibility in designing event websites, invitations, and registration forms, allowing organizers to create a unique and branded event experience.
4. Data Management: The system collects and organizes data, including attendee information, preferences, and engagement levels, providing valuable insights for future events.
5. Collaboration: With features like team access and communication tools, Splash facilitates effective collaboration among event organizers, vendors, and stakeholders.

Cons:
1. Learning Curve: As with any software, there may be a learning curve for new users to familiarize themselves with Splash's interface and features.
2. Cost: Depending on the event's scale and requirements, the cost of using Splash may be a consideration for budget-conscious organizers.
3. Reliance on Technology: Event management systems like Splash heavily rely on technology, making them vulnerable to technical issues, internet connectivity problems, or system downtime.

can windows form application be linked with other devices or at least more than 1 program working on the same database

Yes, a Windows Forms application can be linked with other devices or more than one program working on the same database. 

To achieve this, you can use a database management system (DBMS) such as Microsoft SQL Server, Oracle, or MySQL to store and manage data. The DBMS provides a centralized database server that multiple applications can connect to, and it manages the concurrency and consistency of the data across all connected applications.

In a Windows Forms application, you can use a data access framework such as Entity Framework or ADO.NET to connect to the database server and manipulate data. You can also use various communication protocols such as TCP/IP, UDP, or WebSockets to communicate with other devices or programs over the network.

By leveraging the power of a DBMS and data access framework, you can create a scalable and secure application that can share data across multiple devices and programs. However, you must design your database schema and the data access code in a way that ensures consistency, concurrency, and security.

this is very complicated for me right now I'm using Microsoft SQL server as database and vb.net for the windows form application can you explain to me what should I do but be easy with me I'm new at that

Sure, I'd be happy to explain in simple terms what you can do to link your Windows Forms application with other devices or programs that access the same Microsoft SQL Server database. 

There are two primary tasks involved in achieving this:

1. Configure the Microsoft SQL Server to allow remote connections.
2. Update your VB.NET application to connect to the Microsoft SQL Server database.

To configure Microsoft SQL Server to allow remote connections, you can follow these steps:

1. Open the Microsoft SQL Server Configuration Manager.
2. In the left pane, select SQL Server Network Configuration, and then select Protocols for [your SQL Server instance].
3. Enable the TCP/IP and Named Pipes protocols.
4. In the left pane, select SQL Server Services, and then select SQL Server [your SQL Server instance].
5. In the right pane, select the SQL Server (MSSQLSERVER) service, and then click the Restart button.

To update your VB.NET application to connect to the Microsoft SQL Server database, you can follow these steps:

1. Open your VB.NET project in Visual Studio.
2. Open the Solution Explorer, and then open the file that contains your database connection code.
3. In the database connection string, replace "localhost" or "." with the network name or IP address of your Microsoft SQL Server.
4. Test the connection to verify that you can connect to the Microsoft SQL Server database.

That's it! Once you have updated your VB.NET application to connect to the Microsoft SQL Server, you can share the same database across multiple devices or programs that access the server.

I want to add photos to the windows form as I press a button it shows a specified photo that's name is the button's name how can I do that

To display a photo in a Windows Form application when a button is pressed, you can do the following:

1. Add a PictureBox control to your form where you want the photo to be displayed.

2. Set the PictureBox's size mode property to "Zoom" so that the photo is automatically resized to fit the control.

3. Add an event handler for the button click event where you will load the specified photo.

4. In the event handler, you can load the specified photo by setting the PictureBox's image property to the image file that matches the button's name.

Here is some sample code to get you started:

```
Private Sub btnShowPhoto_Click(sender As Object, e As EventArgs) Handles btnShowPhoto.Click
    ' Load photo with the same name as the button
    Dim photoName As String = btnShowPhoto.Name & ".jpg" ' assuming JPG format
    Dim photoPath As String = Application.StartupPath & "\" & photoName ' assuming the photos are in the application folder
    If System.IO.File.Exists(photoPath) Then
        PictureBox1.Image = Image.FromFile(photoPath)
    Else
        ' Photo not found
        MessageBox.Show("Photo not found: " & photoName)
    End If
End Sub
```

Note that this code assumes that the photos are stored in the same folder as your application and that their file names match the button names. You may need to modify the code if your photos are stored in a different location or if you are using different file formats.

To display a photo for each item in your database and have it displayed when the item name is entered, you will need to have a separate photo associated with each item in the database. You could store the filenames of the photos in the same row of the database table as the items, or you could store the photos in a separate folder and link them to the respective items via a naming convention.

Here are the steps you can follow to display the photo for a given item:

1. When an item name is entered in a textbox, you can use the entered text to query the database for the corresponding row.

2. Once you have the row that matches the entered item name, you can extract the filename of the associated photo from the row.

3. Using the filename, you can load the corresponding photo into a PictureBox control on the form.

Here is sample code that demonstrates how to load the photo for a given item:

```
Private Sub btnShowItem_Click(sender As Object, e As EventArgs) Handles btnShowItem.Click
    Dim itemName As String = txtItemName.Text
    Dim sqlQuery As String = "SELECT * FROM Items WHERE ItemName = '" & itemName & "'"

    Dim connString As String = "Data Source=(localdb)\MSSQLLocalDB;Initial Catalog=YourDatabaseNameHere;Integrated Security=True;"
    Dim conn As New SqlConnection(connString)
    Dim da As New SqlDataAdapter()

    da.SelectCommand = New SqlCommand(sqlQuery, conn)

    Dim ds As New DataSet()
    da.Fill(ds, "Items")

    If (ds.Tables(0).Rows.Count > 0) Then
        Dim itemRow As DataRow = ds.Tables(0).Rows(0)
        Dim photoFileName As String = itemRow("PhotoFileName").ToString()

        If (Not String.IsNullOrEmpty(photoFileName)) Then

                pbItemPhoto.Image = Image.FromFile(photoPath)

        End If
    End If
End Sub
```

Note that this code assumes that the database table is named "Items" and has a column named "PhotoFileName" that stores the filenames of the photos associated with each item. You may need to modify the code to reflect the structure of your own database.
is there any way that I can load some data from database and then make a source of a datagridview then I want to print that data

Yes, you can load data from the database into a DataGridView and then print the data using the PrintDocument and PrintPreviewDialog classes in VB.NET.

Here are the general steps you can follow to achieve this:

1. Query the database and load the data into a DataTable or a DataGridView.

2. Create an instance of the PrintDocument class and add an event handler for the PrintPage event.

3. In the PrintPage event handler, define the layout of the printed page and draw the data onto the page.

4. Create an instance of the PrintPreviewDialog class and assign the PrintDocument to its Document property.

5. Display the print preview dialog to the user.

Here is some sample code to get you started:

```
Private Sub btnPrint_Click(sender As Object, e As EventArgs) Handles btnPrint.Click
    ' Load data from the database into a DataTable or a DataGridView
    Dim dt As New DataTable()
    Dim connString As String = "Data Source=(localdb)\MSSQLLocalDB;Initial Catalog=YourDatabaseNameHere;Integrated Security=True;"
    Dim conn As New SqlConnection(connString)
    Dim da As New SqlDataAdapter("SELECT * FROM YourTableNameHere", conn)
    da.Fill(dt)

    ' Create an instance of the PrintDocument class
    Dim pd As New PrintDocument()

    ' Add an event handler for the PrintPage event
    AddHandler pd.PrintPage, AddressOf PrintPageHandler

    ' Create an instance of the PrintPreviewDialog class and assign the PrintDocument to its Document property
    Dim ppd As New PrintPreviewDialog()
    ppd.Document = pd

    ' Display the print preview dialog to the user
    ppd.ShowDialog()
End Sub

Private Sub PrintPageHandler(sender As Object, e As PrintPageEventArgs)
    ' Define the layout of the printed page
    Dim margins As New Margins(50, 50, 50, 50)
    e.PageSettings.Margins = margins

    ' Draw the data onto the page
    Dim dgv As New DataGridView()
    dgv.DataSource = dt ' dt is the DataTable that contains the data
    dgv.AutoGenerateColumns = True
    dgv.AutoSizeColumnsMode = DataGridViewAutoSizeColumnsMode.AllCells
    dgv.Columns.GetLastColumn(DataGridViewElementStates.Visible, DataGridViewElementStates.None, -1).AutoSizeMode = DataGridViewAutoSizeColumnMode.Fill
    dgv.ScrollBars = ScrollBars.None
    dgv.BorderStyle = BorderStyle.None
    dgv.BackgroundColor = Color.White
    dgv.ColumnHeadersDefaultCellStyle.Font = New Font("Tahoma", 10, FontStyle.Bold)

    Dim height As Integer = dgv.Height + dgv.ColumnHeadersHeight
    For Each row As DataGridViewRow In dgv.Rows
        height += row.Height
    Next

    If height > e.PageBounds.Height Then
        e.HasMorePages = True
    Else
        dgv.DrawToBitmap(Bitmap, New Rectangle(0, 0, dgv.Width, dgv.Height))
        e.Graphics.DrawImage(Bitmap, 50, 50)
        e.HasMorePages = False
    End If
End Sub
```

Note that this code is just a starting point and will need to be modified to fit the structure of your own database and DataGridView. Also, you may need to adjust the layout and formatting of the printed page to fit your own needs.

To use your 802.11n wireless USB adapter, you will need to follow these steps:

1. Install the driver software: The first thing you should do is install the driver software that came with your 802.11n wireless USB adapter. This should install the necessary drivers for the adapter to function properly.

2. Connect the adapter to your computer: Once the drivers are installed, you can connect the 802.11n wireless USB adapter to your computer using the USB port.

3. Set up the wireless network: To connect to a wireless network, you will need to set up a wireless network in your home or office. To do this, you will need a wireless router. Once you have a wireless router, you can set up a wireless network and configure it with a network name (SSID) and a security passphrase.

4. Connect to the wireless network: Once the wireless network is set up, you can connect to it using your 802.11n wireless USB adapter. To do this, you will need to select the wireless network from the list of available networks and enter the security passphrase.

5. Test the connection: Finally, you should test the connection to make sure it is working properly. You can try browsing the internet or transferring files between computers on the network.

Note that the exact steps may vary depending on the specific adapter and router you are using. You may need to consult the documentation that came with your adapter and router for more specific instructions.

If your 802.11n wireless USB adapter is not showing you the list of available networks, it may be due to the following reasons:

1. Driver issues: Ensure that the driver for your 802.11n wireless USB adapter is installed correctly. You can check if the driver is installed correctly by navigating to the "Device Manager" in Windows and looking for any yellow exclamation marks. If the driver fails to install, you may need to download and install the latest driver from the manufacturer's website.

2. Adapter compatibility: Ensure that your 802.11n wireless USB adapter is compatible with your computer and operating system. Check the manufacturer's website to verify compatibility.

3. Adapter configuration: Check the settings of your 802.11n wireless USB adapter to ensure it is working properly. You may need to access the adapter settings by right-clicking on the adapter icon in the system tray and selecting "Properties".

4. Wireless router issues: Check that the wireless router is turned on and broadcasting a signal. Ensure that the router and the adapter are on the same channel and frequency. 

5. Interference: Your wireless signal can be affected by other electronic devices, such as cordless phones, microwaves, or other wireless networks. Keep your adapter and router away from these devices and check if the signal improves.

If none of these solutions work, you may need to contact the manufacturer of the adapter or a technical support service for further assistance.

conversation.content: ecommerce features with explanation

1. Product Catalog: This is the collection of products offered for sale on an ecommerce website. It provides customers with detailed information about each product, including images, descriptions, and prices.

2. Shopping Cart: The shopping cart feature allows customers to add products to their cart while they browse the website. The cart will keep track of all the items a customer wants to purchase, and allow them to easily remove or change the quantity of items in their cart before checking out.

3. Checkout: The checkout process involves verifying the items in a customer's cart, selecting a shipping method, entering payment information, and reviewing the order before finalizing the purchase.

4. Payment Gateway: This is the technology that securely processes the customer's payment information and completes the transaction. It allows the ecommerce website to accept various payment methods, such as credit cards, debit cards, and PayPal.

5. Order Management: After a customer completes a purchase, the order management feature tracks the order's progress, including shipping status and delivery dates. It also generates invoices and sends confirmation emails to customers.

6. Customer Account: An ecommerce website may offer customers the option to create an account, which allows them to store their shipping and billing information, view past orders, and receive special offers.

7. Wish List: A wish list feature allows customers to save items they are interested in purchasing for later. This makes it easier for them to find and purchase these items at a later date.

```python
import sys
import logging
from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.webdriver.common.by import By
from selenium.webdriver.support.ui import WebDriverWait
from selenium.webdriver.support import expected_conditions as EC
from email_handler import send_email
import config

logging.basicConfig(filename='app.log', filemode='w', format='%(asctime)s - %(message)s', level=logging.INFO)

def perform_task(user_inputs):
    username_input, password_input, six_digit, three_digit = user_inputs
    number_of_sales_items = 0
    driver = webdriver.Firefox()

    # Step 1. Navigate to URL
    driver.get('https://mt.metrc.com/log-in?ReturnUrl=%2f')

    # Step 2. Input Username and Password
    username_element = WebDriverWait(driver, 10).until(EC.presence_of_element_located((By.XPATH, "//*[@id='username']")))
    password_element = WebDriverWait(driver, 10).until(EC.presence_of_element_located((By.XPATH, "//*[@id='password']")))
    username_element.send_keys(username_input)
    password_element.send_keys(password_input)
    password_element.submit()

    # Step 3. Navigate to Specific URL
    url = ('https://mt.metrc.com/industry/D-' + six_digit + '-' + three_digit + '/sales/receipts')
    driver.get(url)

    # Step 4. Navigate to Active Tab
    WebDriverWait(driver, 10).until(EC.presence_of_element_located((By.XPATH, "/html/body/div[3]/div[2]/div[2]/div/div[2]/div/ul/li[1]/span[2]"))).click()

    # Step 5. Set Items per Row
    dropdown = WebDriverWait(driver, 10).until(EC.presence_of_element_located((By.XPATH, '/html/body/div[3]/div[2]/div[2]/div/div[2]/div/div[1]/div/div[2]/span[2]/span/span/span[2]/span'))).click()
    WebDriverWait(driver, 10).until(EC.presence_of_element_located((By.CSS_SELECTOR, 'div.k-list-container:nth-child(1) > div:nth-child(2) > ul:nth-child(1) > li:nth-child(5)'))).click()

    # Step 6. Highlight Items
    highlight_script = """
       // Find all elements with role="rowgroup"
       var groups = document.querySelectorAll('[role="rowgroup"]');

       // Loop through each group and add the "k-state-selected" class to every row
       for (var i = 0; i < groups.length; i++) {
           var rows = groups[i].querySelectorAll('tr[class^="k"]');
           for (var j = 0; j < rows.length; j++) {
               rows[j].classList.add('k-state-selected');
           }
       }
    """
    driver.execute_script(highlight_script)
    # Count the number of items and log.
    number_of_sales_items = len(driver.find_elements_by_css_selector('tr.k-state-selected'))
    logging.info(f'Number of sales items: {number_of_sales_items}')

    # Step 7. Click Specific Button
    WebDriverWait(driver, 10).until(EC.presence_of_element_located((By.XPATH,'/html/body/div[3]/div[2]/div[2]/div/div[2]/div/div[1]/div/div[1]/div[2]/button'))).click()
    
    # Step 8. Finalize Sales Packages
    WebDriverWait(driver, 10).until(EC.presence_of_element_located((By.XPATH, '/html/body/div[8]/div[2]/div[2]/form/div/button[1]'))).click()
    logging.info('Finalized selected packages.')

    # Step 9. Send Log Email
    send_email(number_of_sales_items, config.REPORT_EMAIL_RECIPIENT)

    driver.quit()
```

Now, create a new file "email_handler.py":

```python
import smtplib
import config

def send_email(number_of_sales_items, recipient_email):
    subject = 'Sales Items Finalized'
    body = f'A total of {number_of_sales_items} sales items have been finalized.'
    message = f'Subject: {subject}\n\n{body}'

    try:
        with smtplib.SMTP_SSL('smtp.gmail.com', 465) as server:
            server.login(config.EMAIL, config.PASSWORD)
            server.sendmail(config.EMAIL, recipient_email, message)
    except Exception as e:
        print(f'Error sending email: {e}')
```

Tell me Product Attributions database

Sure, here is a basic example of a product attributes database:

1. PRODUCTS - This table could include basic product information such as product name, description, and SKU.

2. ATTRIBUTES - This table could store a list of all the possible attributes that could be associated with a product. For example, if you were building a database for electronics, possible attributes could include display size, processor type, RAM and storage capacity.

3. PRODUCT_ATTRIBUTES - This table would contain the values of the attributes associated with each product. This table would need to have a compound primary key consisting of the product ID and attribute name. For instance, if a product has a particular RAM size, the RAM attribute value for that product will be stored in this table, linked with the corresponding product by its product ID.

4. ATTRIBUTES_VALUES - In case of a nested attribute such as storage capacity, total_storage capacity can be derived from several different storage types. Therefore, the values for these nested attributes would be stored in this table like a sub-category.

5. VARIANTS - In case of a product that has multiple variants, this table could be used. It would include information like product ID, inventory size and color options.

6. MEDIA - In case of products that have accompanying visual media like images or videos, this table would store information on the image location and the product it belongs to.

These tables should give you a basic framework for a product attributes database. You may need to add additional tables or fields depending on the specific requirements of your database.
Tell me Product Features database

Sure! Here is a basic example of a database for product features:

1. PRODUCTS- This table would contain information about each product, including product ID, name, description, and any other relevant data.

2. FEATURES- This table would contain a list of all the possible features that could be associated with a product. For example, if you were building a database for smartphones, possible features could include screen size, camera quality, battery capacity, and so on.

3. PRODUCT FEATURES- This table would link the product IDs with their associated features. Each product feature would have its own row in this table, containing the product ID, feature ID, and any additional information specific to that product-feature combination. This table would need to have a compound primary key consisting of the product ID and feature ID.

4. FEATURE VALUES- This table would store all the possible values for each feature. For example, for screen size feature, the values might include 5 inches, 5.5 inches, 6 inches, and so on.

5. PRODUCT FEATURE VALUES- This table would store the specific value of each feature for each product. This table would need to have a compound primary key consisting of the product ID, feature ID, and the feature value.

6. MEDIA- This table could also be used to store visual media like images or videos of the product features. It would include information like the media location and the feature it belongs to.

These tables should give you a basic framework for a product features database. You may need to add additional tables or fields depending on the specific requirements of your database.

1. USERS - This table would contain information about each user, including user ID, username, email, and other relevant data.

2. POSTS - This table would store data related to each post made by a user, including post ID, user ID, timestamp, post content, and other data as required.

3. COMMENTS - This table would store data related to each comment made by a user on a post, including comment ID, post ID, user ID, timestamp, comment content, and other data as required.

4. LIKES - This table would store data related to each like made by a user on a post or comment, including like ID, user ID, post or comment ID, and timestamp.

5. SHARES - This table would track data related to each time a user shares a post or comment, including share ID, user ID, post or comment ID, and timestamp.

6. FOLLOWERS - This table would track which users are following which other users, including follower ID and followee ID.

7. FRIENDSHIPS - This table would store data on which users are friends with each other, including friendship ID, user 1 ID, user 2 ID, and the date the friendship was established.

8. NOTIFICATIONS - This table would track notifications sent to users, including notification ID, user ID, timestamp, type of notification (e.g., new followers, comments, likes), and any other relevant data.

These tables should give you a basic framework for a social media interaction database. You may need to add additional tables or fields depending on the specific requirements of your application.
